module.title: verbal nouns
module.p: Verbal nouns are a subclass of deverbal nouns ie. derived common nouns which are derived from verbs. For example –

ul.li: The (masculine) verbal noun sgrìobhadh writing is derived from the verb sgrìobh write.
The (feminine) verbal noun cluinntinn hearing is derived from the verb cluinn hear.
The (feminine) verbal noun seinn singing is derived from the verb seinn sing.

module.p: The default way of deriving a (masculine) verbal noun from a verb involves deslenderising (where possible) the verbal root and adding the suffix -adh eg.

ul.li: coinnich meet → coinneachadh meeting
sgrìobh write → sgrìobhadh writing
biadhaich feed → biadhachadh feeding

module.p: The plural of a regular verbal noun in -adh ends in -aidhean eg. sgrìobhaidhean writings.
However, there is a very large number of idiosyncratic verbal nouns, even for otherwise regular verbs. A comprehensive list is available here.
When a verbal noun is formed from a transitive verb, the object of the verb is expressed as the specifier of the verbal noun eg. sgrìobadh an leabhair writing the book, biadhachadh chon feeding dogs.
When the object is a personal pronoun, it is expressed as a personal determiner (‘possessive adjective’) specifying the verbal noun eg. mo fhaicinn seeing me, an leughadh reading them.
Verbal nouns have the following main uses –

ul.li: As the complement of the progressive particle ag eg. tha mi a’ biadhachadh nan con I am feeding the dogs.
As the complement of the preposition do when used to express intention eg. thàinig mi do bhiadhachadh nan con I came to feed the dogs

module.p: Verbal nouns are also used in infinitivals, though the syntax of objects is somewhat different.

box.title: verbal nouns – objects as post-specifiers
box.p: When a verbal noun is formed from a transitive verb, a noun object of the verb is expressed as a genitive post-specifier of the verbal noun eg.

ul.li: sgrìobh an leabhar write the book → sgrìobadh an leabhair writing the book
leugh an litir read the letter → leughadh na litreach reading the letter
ith na h-ùbhlan eat the apples → ithe nan ùbhlan eating the apples
faic bean a’ mhinisteir see the minister’s wife → faicinn bean a’ mhinisteir seeing the minister’s wife
biadhaich coin feed dogs → biadhachadh chon feeding dogs

box.p: As with other common nouns, this object-cum-specifier is usually in the genitive case (unless it has a post-specifier itself).
In traditional Gaelic, this was also true for non-specified singular nouns eg.

ul.li: sgrìobh leabhar write a book → sgrìobhadh leabhair writing a book
leugh litir read a letter → leughadh litreach reading a letter
biadhaich cù feed a dog → biadhachadh coin feeding a dog

box.p: However, this latter usage is nowadays perceived to be archaic, with nominative case preferred for non-specified singular objects-cum-specifiers –

Notes –
in contemporary vernacular Gaelic, use of the nominative with plural and specified noun objects is increasingly common eg. leughadh an litir reading the letter, ithe na h-ùbhlan eating the apples, biadhachadh coin feeding dogs.
External sources – gràmar-g

box.title: verbal nouns – objects as pre-specifiers
box.p: When a verbal noun is formed from a transitive verb, a pronoun object of the verb is expressed as a personal determiner pre-specifier (‘possessive adjective’) of the verbal noun eg.

ul.li: faic mi see me → mo fhaicinn seeing me, lit. my seeing
biadhaich sibh feed you → (bh)ur biadhachadh feeding you, lit. your feeding
leugh iad read them → an leughadh reading them, lit. their reading

box.p: Emphatic pronoun objects are expressed using emphatic personal determiners –

ul.li: faic mise see me → mo fhaicinn-sa seeing me, lit. my seeing
biadhaich sibhse feed you → (bh)ur biadhachadh-se feeding you, lit. your feeding
leugh iadsan read them → an leughadh-san reading them, lit. their reading

box.p: Reflexive pronoun objects can be emphasised using fhèin self as follows –

ul.li: faic mi fhìn see myself → mo fhaicinn fhìn seeing myself
biadhaich sibh fhèin feed you → (bh)ur biadhachadh fhèin feeding yourself

box.p: It is important to note that usages like faicinn mi or leughadh iadsan or biadhachadh sibh fhèin are ungrammatical in Gaelic.
However, demonstrative pronouns do follow the verbal noun (with no need for a definite article) eg.

ul.li: faic seo see this → faicinn seo seeing this
leugh sin read that → leughadh seo reading that
